questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the first step when diagnosing a no-crank condition on heavy equipment?

options.B: Replace the starter motor immediately.

explanations.A: Alternator testing is for charging issues, not starting problems.
explanations.B: Starter replacement should only occur after diagnosis confirms failure.
explanations.C: Battery voltage and connections must be verified first as they are the primary power source.
explanations.D: Fuel system does not affect cranking ability.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: A battery load test shows the voltage drops to 8.5V under load. What does this indicate?

options.B: Battery requires a slow charge.
options.C: Battery has failed and requires replacement.

explanations.A: Voltage dropping below 9.6V indicates failure.
explanations.B: A failed battery cannot be recovered by charging.
explanations.C: Dirty terminals would show high resistance, not low voltage under load.
explanations.D: Voltage below 9.6V under load indicates internal cell failure.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the typical voltage output of a properly functioning alternator at idle speed?

explanations.A: This is battery resting voltage, not charging voltage.
explanations.B: Overcharging condition that can damage batteries and electronics.
explanations.C: Normal alternator output ranges from 13.5 to 14.5 volts.
explanations.D: Indicates undercharging or alternator failure.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What causes a starter solenoid to click but not engage the starter motor?

options.B: Low battery voltage or poor connections.

explanations.A: Ignition switch failure would prevent clicking entirely.
explanations.B: Insufficient voltage prevents the solenoid from fully engaging the starter.
explanations.C: Fuel pump does not affect starter operation.
explanations.D: Drive belt does not affect starting system.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: During a charging system test, the alternator output is only 12.8V at 2000 RPM. What is the most likely cause?

options.B: Loose battery terminals.

explanations.A: Loose terminals affect voltage drop but not alternator output voltage.
explanations.B: Voltage regulator failure prevents proper charging voltage output.
explanations.C: Starter motor does not affect charging system operation.
explanations.D: Oil pressure has no effect on electrical charging.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What tool is used to measure the amperage draw of a starter motor during cranking?

options.B: Inductive ammeter or current clamp.

explanations.A: Voltage measurement does not show current draw.
explanations.B: Ohmmeter measures resistance, not current flow.
explanations.C: Inductive ammeter safely measures high amperage without breaking circuit.
explanations.D: Test light only indicates presence of voltage.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: A battery shows 12.4V at rest but drops to 10V when attempting to start. What is the problem?

options.B: Battery has high internal resistance.
options.C: Starter motor is drawing excessive current.

explanations.A: Alternator only charges when engine is running.
explanations.B: While possible, battery weakness is more likely with this voltage drop.
explanations.C: Excessive voltage drop indicates weak battery with high internal resistance.
explanations.D: Overcharged batteries show higher voltage, not lower under load.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the purpose of the alternator voltage regulator?

options.A: To increase battery voltage during starting.
options.B: To maintain consistent charging voltage regardless of load.
options.C: To reduce voltage to the starter motor.

explanations.A: Voltage regulator controls charging, not starting voltage.
explanations.B: Temperature sensing is a separate function in some systems.
explanations.C: Regulator has no connection to starter motor circuit.
explanations.D: Regulator maintains proper charging voltage under varying loads and speeds.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When performing a voltage drop test on the positive battery cable during cranking, what is the maximum acceptable voltage drop?

options.B: 0.5 volts.

explanations.A: While ideal, 0.1V is difficult to achieve in heavy equipment applications.
explanations.B: Excessive voltage drop indicating high resistance.
explanations.C: Maximum acceptable voltage drop is 0.5V on positive cable during cranking.
explanations.D: Severely excessive drop requiring immediate repair.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is indicated when an alternator produces AC voltage at the output terminal?

options.B: Faulty diodes in the rectifier bridge.

explanations.A: Alternator output should be DC voltage only.
explanations.B: Failed diodes allow AC voltage to pass through instead of being rectified to DC.
explanations.C: Overcharging relates to voltage level, not AC ripple.
explanations.D: Regulator controls voltage level, not rectification.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: A vehicle experiences slow cranking speed only when the engine is hot. What is the most likely cause?

options.B: Heat-damaged starter motor.

explanations.A: Weak battery would cause slow cranking regardless of temperature.
explanations.B: Heat soak causes internal starter components to expand and bind.
explanations.C: Alternator does not affect cranking when starting.
explanations.D: Oil viscosity affects cranking resistance, not just when hot.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the correct procedure to test for parasitic battery drain?

options.B: Connect ammeter in series with negative battery cable.
options.C: Use test light across battery terminals.

explanations.A: Voltmeter measures voltage, not current drain.
explanations.B: Resistance measurement does not show current drain.
explanations.C: Test light only indicates presence of current, not amount.
explanations.D: Ammeter in series measures current draw with all systems off.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: During alternator testing, the drive belt tension is found to be loose. What effect does this have?

options.B: Causes alternator to overheat.
options.C: Reduces charging output due to belt slippage.
options.D: Has no effect on charging system.

explanations.A: Loose belt reduces, not increases, output.
explanations.B: Belt slippage prevents alternator from reaching proper speed, reducing output.
explanations.C: While it may contribute to heat, the primary issue is reduced output.
explanations.D: Belt tension directly affects alternator performance.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the purpose of the battery hold-down clamp?

options.B: To prevent battery movement and case damage.

explanations.A: Hold-down clamp does not affect electrical connection.
explanations.B: Hold-down has no effect on voltage output.
explanations.C: Prevents physical damage from vibration and movement during operation.
explanations.D: Charging regulation is handled by voltage regulator.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: A starter motor runs continuously after the engine starts. What is the most likely cause?

options.B: Low battery voltage.

explanations.A: Alternator does not control starter operation.
explanations.B: Low voltage would prevent starting, not cause continuous operation.
explanations.C: Stuck solenoid keeps starter engaged even after key is released.
explanations.D: Ignition timing does not affect starter engagement.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What safety precaution must be taken before disconnecting a battery on heavy equipment?

options.B: Turn off all electrical loads and ignition.

explanations.A: Engine should be off before battery disconnection.
explanations.B: Jumper cables are not needed for disconnection.
explanations.C: Prevents voltage spikes and protects electronic components.
explanations.D: Fuse removal is not necessary before battery disconnection.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When testing battery specific gravity, a reading of 1.200 indicates what condition?

options.B: Battery is at 50% charge.
options.C: Battery is discharged and may be sulfated.

explanations.A: Fully charged reads approximately 1.265.
explanations.B: 50% charge would read approximately 1.225-1.230.
explanations.C: Overcharge does not reduce specific gravity.
explanations.D: 1.200 indicates severely discharged battery, likely with sulfation.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the function of the starter drive mechanism (Bendix)?

options.B: To engage and disengage pinion gear from flywheel.

explanations.A: Meshes pinion with ring gear during start and disengages after.
explanations.B: Bendix controls engagement, not motor speed.
explanations.C: Voltage regulation is handled by alternator regulator.
explanations.D: Cooling is not a function of the drive mechanism.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: An alternator shows normal voltage output but the battery warning light remains illuminated. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Broken alternator belt.

explanations.A: Broken belt would prevent charging entirely.
explanations.B: Diode trio failure prevents excitation current to warning light circuit.
explanations.C: Discharged battery would not cause warning light to stay on with proper charging.
explanations.D: Ignition switch does not control warning light when engine running.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the correct method to clean battery terminals with corrosion?

options.A: Use baking soda and water solution, then wire brush.
options.B: Apply battery acid to dissolve corrosion.

explanations.A: Oil-based products attract dirt and do not clean corrosion.
explanations.B: Adding acid increases corrosion and is dangerous.
explanations.C: Sandpaper alone does not neutralize acid residue.
explanations.D: Baking soda neutralizes acid corrosion, wire brush removes residue.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: During starter motor testing on the bench, the motor draws 300 amps at no load. What does this indicate?

options.B: Internal short or grounded armature.

explanations.A: No-load draw should be 60-90 amps typically.
explanations.B: This is a bench test, not affected by vehicle connections.
explanations.C: Excessive current indicates internal short circuit in starter motor.
explanations.D: Even heavy equipment starters should not draw this much at no load.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What causes excessive voltage drop in the ground circuit during cranking?

options.B: Poor ground connections or corroded cables.

explanations.A: Corrosion and loose connections increase resistance in ground path.
explanations.B: Battery charge state does not cause ground circuit resistance.
explanations.C: Alternator output does not affect ground circuit resistance.
explanations.D: Compression affects engine load, not electrical resistance.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: An alternator with a failed stator winding will exhibit what symptom?

options.A: Excessive AC ripple voltage and low output.
options.B: Overcharging condition.
options.C: Normal charging with battery light on.

explanations.A: Failed stator phase causes high AC ripple and reduced DC output.
explanations.B: Failed stator reduces, not increases, charging output.
explanations.C: Charging would be reduced, not normal.
explanations.D: Stator failure causes consistent low output, not intermittent.

questions.subtask: F-13.01 Diagnoses starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the purpose of the neutral safety switch in the starting circuit?

options.B: To increase starter motor speed.

explanations.A: Prevents starter engagement unless transmission is in neutral or park.
explanations.B: Neutral safety switch controls circuit continuity, not motor speed.
explanations.C: Voltage regulation is handled by alternator regulator.
explanations.D: Switch is part of the ignition circuit, not a bypass.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the most common cause of wiper motor failure on heavy equipment?

options.B: Excessive load from binding linkage or seized pivots.

explanations.A: Binding creates excessive current draw and overheats motor.
explanations.B: Washer fluid level does not affect wiper motor.
explanations.C: Blade size does not typically cause motor failure.
explanations.D: While low voltage affects performance, mechanical binding is more common cause of failure.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A blower motor operates only on high speed. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Defective blower motor.

explanations.A: Motor failure would prevent all speeds from operating.
explanations.B: Resistor pack failure eliminates lower speeds, allowing only direct high speed.
explanations.C: Low voltage would affect all speeds equally.
explanations.D: Clogged filter reduces airflow but does not affect speed settings.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When diagnosing a non-functional horn, what should be checked first?

options.B: Check fuse and relay operation.

explanations.A: Relay should be tested before replacement.
explanations.B: Alternator does not affect horn operation directly.
explanations.C: Button should be tested, but fuse and relay are checked first.
explanations.D: Fuse and relay are most common failure points and easiest to check.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What causes an electric cooling fan to run continuously even when the engine is cold?

options.B: Stuck closed relay contacts.

explanations.A: Relay contacts welded closed keep fan powered constantly.
explanations.B: Sensor failure would prevent fan from running or cause delayed operation.
explanations.C: Coolant level does not cause continuous fan operation.
explanations.D: Thermostat affects engine temperature, not electric fan circuit.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A headlight illuminates dimly on one side only. What is the most likely cause?

options.B: Poor ground connection at that headlight.

explanations.A: Poor ground creates resistance, reducing brightness on affected side only.
explanations.B: Alternator issue would affect both headlights.
explanations.C: Low battery affects both lights equally.
explanations.D: Switch failure would affect both headlights or prevent operation.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What tool is best suited for diagnosing an intermittent electrical component failure?

options.B: Oscilloscope or graphing multimeter.

explanations.A: Torque wrench is for fastener tightening, not electrical diagnosis.
explanations.B: Compression tester is for engine cylinder testing.
explanations.C: Captures voltage fluctuations over time to identify intermittent faults.
explanations.D: Feeler gauge measures clearances, not electrical signals.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A gauge shows erratic readings. What is the first diagnostic step?

options.B: Check ground connections and wiring to the sensor.

explanations.A: Gauge cluster should only be replaced after diagnosis confirms failure.
explanations.B: ECM programming does not typically cause erratic analog gauge readings.
explanations.C: Sending unit should be tested, not replaced first.
explanations.D: Poor grounds and loose connections are most common cause of erratic readings.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What causes power windows to operate slowly?

options.B: Worn motor brushes or binding regulator mechanism.

explanations.A: Window tint does not affect motor operation.
explanations.B: Fuel injectors do not affect electrical accessories.
explanations.C: Tire pressure has no relation to window operation.
explanations.D: Worn brushes reduce motor efficiency and binding increases load.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When diagnosing a failed fuel gauge, what component should be tested first?

options.B: Fuel level sending unit and wiring.

explanations.A: Fuel pump does not affect gauge operation.
explanations.B: Injectors are unrelated to fuel level indication.
explanations.C: Fuel filter does not affect gauge operation.
explanations.D: Sending unit resistance changes with fuel level to drive gauge reading.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A turn signal flashes rapidly on one side. What is the cause?

options.B: Overcharged battery.

explanations.A: While possible, burned bulb is more common cause.
explanations.B: Battery charge state does not affect flasher speed.
explanations.C: Reduced load from failed bulb causes flasher to cycle faster.
explanations.D: Coolant level has no effect on turn signals.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the function of a relay in an electrical circuit?

options.B: To use low current to control high current circuits.
options.D: To convert AC to DC voltage.

explanations.A: Relays do not change voltage levels.
explanations.B: Voltage conversion is function of rectifier, not relay.
explanations.C: Relay does not reduce amperage, it controls circuit.
explanations.D: Allows small switch current to control large load currents safely.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A backup alarm fails to sound. What should be checked first?

options.B: Alarm fuse and reverse switch operation.

explanations.A: Fuse and reverse switch are primary causes of alarm failure.
explanations.B: Fluid level does not affect alarm operation.
explanations.C: Oil pressure is unrelated to backup alarm.
explanations.D: Tire sensors do not affect backup alarm.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What causes instrument panel lights to dim when the blower motor is turned on?

options.B: High resistance in power supply or poor ground connection.

explanations.A: Dimming indicates electrical problem, not normal operation.
explanations.B: Poor connection causes voltage drop under increased load.
explanations.C: Coolant level does not affect electrical circuits.
explanations.D: Fuel pressure is unrelated to electrical dimming.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When testing a motor for a short to ground, what reading indicates a problem?

options.B: Low resistance (near zero ohms).

explanations.A: Infinite resistance indicates good insulation, no short.
explanations.B: Temperature does not indicate short to ground.
explanations.C: Motors do not produce voltage output.
explanations.D: Low resistance between motor circuit and ground indicates short.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A power seat moves slowly in one direction but normally in others. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Failed seat motor.
options.C: Worn or dirty switch contacts for that direction.

explanations.A: Poor contact creates resistance, reducing current to motor in one direction.
explanations.B: Motor failure would affect all directions.
explanations.C: Low battery would affect all directions equally.
explanations.D: Position sensor does not control motor speed.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the correct method to test a suspect electrical connector?

options.B: Measure voltage drop across connector under load.

explanations.A: Visual inspection may miss internal corrosion.
explanations.B: Voltage drop test reveals resistance caused by poor connection.
explanations.C: Testing should be done before applying any treatment.
explanations.D: Proper diagnosis should precede replacement.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A hydraulic fan motor operates intermittently. What electrical component should be checked?

options.A: Fan motor solenoid and wiring connections.
options.B: Alternator voltage regulator.

explanations.A: Solenoid controls hydraulic fan motor engagement, loose connections cause intermittent operation.
explanations.B: Voltage regulator affects charging, not specific motor operation.
explanations.C: Starter motor is unrelated to hydraulic fan operation.
explanations.D: While important, battery terminals alone don't explain intermittent fan operation.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What causes excessive current draw in an electric motor?

options.B: High battery voltage.

explanations.A: Clean connections reduce resistance and current draw.
explanations.B: High voltage increases speed but doesn't necessarily increase current with normal load.
explanations.C: Mechanical resistance increases load, causing higher current draw.
explanations.D: Proper lubrication reduces current draw, not increases it.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When diagnosing work lights that do not illuminate, what is checked after verifying fuse integrity?

options.B: Switch operation and bulb condition.

explanations.A: Switch and bulbs are next most common failure points after fuse.
explanations.B: Compression has no relation to lighting circuits.
explanations.C: Fluid level is unrelated to lighting operation.
explanations.D: Brake pads do not affect work lights.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: A temperature gauge reads high but the engine is not overheating. What is the probable cause?

options.B: Faulty temperature sending unit.

explanations.A: Fan failure would cause actual overheating.
explanations.B: Tire pressure is unrelated to temperature indication.
explanations.C: Fuel level does not affect temperature gauge.
explanations.D: Sending unit failure provides incorrect resistance to gauge.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the purpose of a circuit breaker in heavy equipment electrical systems?

options.B: To automatically reset protection after overload.
options.C: To convert AC to DC power.

explanations.A: Circuit breaker protects circuits, does not increase voltage.
explanations.B: Resets automatically or manually after cooling, unlike fuses.
explanations.C: Rectification is performed by diodes, not breakers.
explanations.D: Breaker protects circuits, does not affect alternator.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: An electric radiator fan fails to shut off after engine cooldown. What should be inspected?

options.B: Temperature sensor and fan relay.

explanations.A: Oil pressure does not control cooling fan.
explanations.B: Stuck relay or failed temp sensor causes continuous fan operation.
explanations.C: Fuel system does not affect fan operation.
explanations.D: Transmission sensor is unrelated to cooling fan.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What does a diode do in an electrical circuit?

options.A: Allows current flow in one direction only.
options.B: Increases voltage output.

explanations.A: Diode does not increase voltage.
explanations.B: Diode acts as one-way valve for electrical current.
explanations.C: Capacitor stores energy, not diode.
explanations.D: Diode blocks reverse current flow.

questions.subtask: F-13.02 Diagnoses electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: During accessory diagnosis, what indicates a short circuit in the wiring?

options.B: Fuse blows immediately when circuit is energized.

explanations.A: Short creates excessive current draw, immediately blowing fuse.
explanations.B: Open circuit draws no current, not short circuit.
explanations.C: Short circuit would prevent normal operation.
explanations.D: Slow operation indicates high resistance, not short.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the correct procedure for replacing a battery in heavy equipment?

options.B: Disconnect negative first, reconnect negative last.
options.C: Disconnect positive first, reconnect positive last.

explanations.A: This is the connection sequence, but disconnection order is opposite.
explanations.B: Disconnecting negative first prevents shorts; reconnecting it last prevents sparks near battery.
explanations.C: Increases risk of shorting tools against chassis.
explanations.D: Proper sequence must be followed for safety.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When installing a new alternator, what must be done before connecting the wiring?

options.B: Verify correct pulley alignment and belt tension.

explanations.A: Engine should not be started until installation is complete.
explanations.B: Voltage regulator should remain connected unless being replaced.
explanations.C: Mechanical installation should be verified before electrical connections.
explanations.D: Proper alignment and tension prevent premature failure and belt damage.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the proper method to install new battery cables?

options.A: Route cables away from heat sources and moving parts, secure properly.
options.B: Allow cables to contact exhaust manifolds for heat dissipation.
options.C: Route loosely without securing to allow flexibility.
options.D: Bundle with fuel lines for organization.

explanations.A: Fuel lines and electrical cables should be separated.
explanations.B: Heat exposure damages insulation and creates fire hazard.
explanations.C: Unsecured cables can chafe, short, or disconnect from vibration.
explanations.D: Prevents heat damage, chafing, and ensures reliable connections.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: After replacing a starter motor, what should be verified before operation?

options.B: Starter mounting bolts torque, electrical connections, and pinion gear engagement.

explanations.A: Mechanical mounting is equally important.
explanations.B: Ensures proper installation, prevents damage during cranking.
explanations.C: Battery charge alone does not verify proper starter installation.
explanations.D: Alternator is not directly related to starter installation verification.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When replacing an alternator belt, what is the correct tension specification?

options.A: As tight as possible by hand.
options.B: Loose enough to prevent noise.
options.C: According to manufacturer's specifications using proper gauge.
options.D: Tight enough to prevent any deflection.

explanations.A: Hand tightening is inconsistent and often incorrect.
explanations.B: Proper tension ensures efficient operation without bearing damage.
explanations.C: Loose belt will slip and reduce charging.
explanations.D: Some deflection is normal and specified; excessive tension damages bearings.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What safety precaution must be taken when working on a charging system?

options.A: Keep engine running during all tests.
options.B: Disconnect battery negative cable before removing alternator.
options.C: Short circuit alternator output to test.

explanations.A: Engine should be off for most service procedures.
explanations.B: Prevents accidental shorts and protects electronics during service.
explanations.C: Shorting alternator output can cause severe damage.
explanations.D: Jumper cables are not needed during service.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When installing battery terminals, what ensures a proper connection?

options.B: Apply grease before tightening.
options.C: Clean posts and terminals, torque to specifications, apply protective coating after.

explanations.A: Proper torque is required for good electrical contact.
explanations.B: Grease before tightening prevents proper metal-to-metal contact.
explanations.C: Over-tightening can damage terminals and posts.
explanations.D: Clean connection, proper torque, and post-installation protection ensure reliability.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the correct procedure for bench testing a starter motor?

options.A: Connect directly to battery and run continuously.
options.B: Secure starter in vise, connect to power source, test no-load and load current.
options.C: Test while still mounted on engine.

explanations.A: Continuous operation will overheat and damage starter.
explanations.B: Bench test requires removal for accurate measurement.
explanations.C: Proper bench test safely measures performance characteristics.
explanations.D: Water exposure will damage electrical components.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: After alternator replacement, the warning light stays on. What should be checked?

options.B: Wiring connections to alternator and regulator, drive belt tension.

explanations.A: Mounting does not affect warning light circuit.
explanations.B: Coolant level does not affect alternator warning light.
explanations.C: Tire pressure is unrelated to charging system.
explanations.D: Loose connections or improper belt tension prevent charging and keep light on.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What is the purpose of applying dielectric grease to electrical connections?

options.B: To seal out moisture and prevent corrosion.

explanations.A: Protects connections from moisture and corrosion, ensuring long-term reliability.
explanations.B: Dielectric grease is non-conductive.
explanations.C: Grease does not change voltage.
explanations.D: Grease protects connections but does not reduce amperage.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: When replacing a solenoid on a starter motor, what must be verified?

options.A: Solenoid part number matches, mounting is secure, connections are tight.
options.B: Only that it fits physically.

explanations.A: Alternator output is separate from solenoid replacement verification.
explanations.B: Electrical specifications must also match.
explanations.C: Ensures proper fit, function, and reliable electrical connection.
explanations.D: Battery should be charged for proper testing.

questions.subtask: F-14.01 Repairs starting/charging systems and batteries
questions.question: What should be done if excessive voltage drop is found in the positive battery cable?

options.B: Replace or repair the cable to eliminate high resistance.

explanations.A: Increasing alternator output does not fix cable resistance.
explanations.B: Starter current is determined by engine load and motor condition, not adjustable.
explanations.C: Additional batteries do not fix cable resistance problem.
explanations.D: Cable replacement eliminates resistance and restores proper voltage delivery.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When replacing a blower motor resistor, what should be inspected first?

options.B: Blower motor for excessive current draw or binding.

explanations.A: Excessive motor current from binding causes resistor burnout; must fix root cause.
explanations.B: Alternator voltage does not typically cause resistor failure.
explanations.C: Battery terminals are not primary cause of resistor failure.
explanations.D: Fuel pump is unrelated to blower motor circuit.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the correct procedure for replacing a wiper motor?

options.A: Disconnect battery, mark linkage position, remove motor, install and adjust new motor.
options.B: Leave battery connected and replace motor quickly.

explanations.A: Proper sequence ensures safety, correct installation, and proper operation.
explanations.B: Battery must be disconnected for safety.
explanations.C: Windshield removal is unnecessary for motor replacement.
explanations.D: Only motor needs replacement if other components are functional.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When installing a replacement relay, what must be verified?

options.B: Relay pin configuration, voltage rating, and current capacity match.

explanations.A: Physical fit alone does not ensure proper electrical operation.
explanations.B: Brand is less important than electrical specifications.
explanations.C: Color is not an electrical specification.
explanations.D: Pin configuration and ratings must match to prevent failure or damage.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the proper method to repair a damaged wire harness?

options.B: Use proper connectors or solder and heat shrink tubing, route away from hazards.

explanations.A: Proper repair ensures reliable connection, protection from moisture and vibration.
explanations.B: Twist and tape connections are unreliable and unsafe.
explanations.C: Tape alone provides inadequate connection and protection.
explanations.D: Complete replacement is unnecessary for localized damage.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When replacing a headlight bulb, what safety precaution is required?

options.A: Ensure lights are off and cool, avoid touching halogen bulb glass.
options.B: Keep lights on during replacement.
options.C: Use bare hands to install for better grip.

explanations.A: Skin oils on halogen bulbs cause premature failure.
explanations.B: Lights must be off for safety.
explanations.C: Prevents burns and oil contamination that shortens bulb life.
explanations.D: Engine operation is irrelevant but lights should be off.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the correct method to install a replacement horn?

options.A: Mount securely, connect wiring, verify ground connection, test operation.
options.B: Connect wires only, leave loose for easy replacement.
options.C: Mount in any location regardless of moisture exposure.

explanations.A: Horn must be securely mounted to prevent damage from vibration.
explanations.B: Proper mounting, wiring, and testing ensure reliable operation.
explanations.C: Location should protect from moisture and debris.
explanations.D: Testing verifies correct installation before completing job.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When repairing a gauge sending unit, what should be checked?

options.A: Sending unit resistance values at various positions match specifications.
options.B: Physical appearance only.

explanations.A: Internal electrical values must be tested, not just visual inspection.
explanations.B: Resistance values must be within specs to provide accurate gauge readings.
explanations.C: Alternator output does not directly affect sending unit function.
explanations.D: Tire pressure is unrelated to gauge sending units.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the proper procedure for replacing a cooling fan motor?

options.A: Disconnect battery, drain coolant if necessary, remove fan assembly, install new motor.
options.B: Replace while engine is hot.
options.D: Do not drain coolant under any circumstances.

explanations.A: Battery must be disconnected to prevent shorts and injury.
explanations.B: Hot engine creates burn hazard.
explanations.C: Ensures safety and prevents coolant loss during removal.
explanations.D: Some installations require partial coolant drain for access.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When installing a new switch, what ensures proper operation?

options.A: Correct wiring connections per schematic, proper mounting, operational testing.
options.B: Random wire connection.
options.C: Loose mounting for easy future access.

explanations.A: Proper wiring, secure mounting, and testing ensure reliable function.
explanations.B: Incorrect wiring can cause malfunction or damage.
explanations.C: Switch must be securely mounted for reliable operation.
explanations.D: Testing verifies proper installation.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What should be done before soldering electrical connections?

options.A: Clean wire ends, ensure proper heat application, use rosin core solder.
options.B: Use acid core solder on all connections.
options.D: Solder while wires are installed in vehicle.

explanations.A: Clean wires, proper technique, and correct solder type ensure good connection.
explanations.B: Acid core solder causes corrosion in electrical circuits.
explanations.C: Clean wires are essential for proper solder adhesion.
explanations.D: Wires should be removed or protected from heat damage to surrounding components.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: When replacing a power window motor, what must be considered?

options.A: Motor torque rating and mounting configuration.
options.B: Window tint darkness.

explanations.A: Paint color is irrelevant to motor choice.
explanations.B: Tint does not affect motor selection.
explanations.C: Motor must have adequate torque and proper mounting for reliable operation.
explanations.D: Tire size has no relation to window motor.

questions.subtask: F-14.02 Repairs electrical components, motors and accessories
questions.question: What is the correct method to replace a backup alarm?

options.A: Disconnect power, mount alarm securely, connect wiring, test in reverse.
options.B: Mount alarm but do not test.
options.D: Install while transmission is in reverse.

explanations.A: Alarm must be securely mounted to prevent damage.
explanations.B: Testing is critical to verify operation.
explanations.C: Proper installation and testing ensure alarm functions when needed.
explanations.D: Transmission should be in park/neutral during installation.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What tool is required to read diagnostic trouble codes from an electronic control module?

options.B: Diagnostic scan tool or code reader.

explanations.A: Torque wrench is for fasteners, not diagnostics.
explanations.B: Test light only indicates voltage presence.
explanations.C: Scan tool communicates with ECM to retrieve stored fault codes.
explanations.D: Feeler gauge measures clearances, not electronic data.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What does a pending diagnostic trouble code indicate?

options.A: A fault was detected once but not confirmed yet.
options.B: A permanent system failure.

explanations.A: Pending code indicates single occurrence; becomes active if fault repeats.
explanations.B: Permanent codes indicate confirmed failures.
explanations.C: Any trouble code indicates abnormal operation.
explanations.D: Battery condition is separate from pending codes.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What is the first step after retrieving diagnostic trouble codes?

options.B: Record codes and refer to service manual for diagnostic procedures.
options.D: Ignore codes if vehicle operates normally.

explanations.A: Codes must be diagnosed and repaired before clearing.
explanations.B: ECM replacement is last resort after proper diagnosis.
explanations.C: Proper documentation and following procedures ensures correct diagnosis.
explanations.D: Codes indicate problems that may worsen if ignored.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What does an active diagnostic trouble code indicate?

options.A: Fault was present in the past but is currently resolved.
options.B: Fault is currently present or occurred multiple times.

explanations.A: This describes a historic or stored code.
explanations.B: Active code indicates current problem or repeated occurrence.
explanations.C: Active codes always indicate a problem.
explanations.D: Active code is legitimate system fault.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: When should diagnostic trouble codes be cleared?

options.B: After repair is completed and verified.

explanations.A: Codes provide diagnostic information needed for repair.
explanations.B: Clear only after repair is confirmed successful to verify fix.
explanations.C: Premature clearing loses diagnostic information.
explanations.D: Codes should be cleared after successful repair.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What does a sensor circuit high voltage code typically indicate?

options.A: Open circuit, short to voltage, or failed sensor.
options.B: Low battery voltage.

explanations.A: Fuel pressure does not cause sensor voltage codes.
explanations.B: Low battery would cause low voltage codes.
explanations.C: High voltage code always indicates a fault.
explanations.D: High voltage codes indicate open circuit or short to power source.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: When multiple DTCs are present, which should be diagnosed first?

options.B: Oldest stored code or codes that could cause other codes.

explanations.A: Oldest code or primary fault should be addressed first.
explanations.B: Primary faults often cause secondary codes; fix root cause first.
explanations.C: Systematic approach prevents misdiagnosis.
explanations.D: Proper diagnosis should precede any component replacement.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What does a sensor circuit low voltage code typically indicate?

options.B: Short to ground, poor connection, or failed sensor.

explanations.A: Low voltage indicates ground short, connection problem, or sensor failure.
explanations.B: Battery charge state does not cause sensor low voltage.
explanations.C: Alternator output affects system voltage, not sensor signal.
explanations.D: Low voltage code indicates fault, not normal operation.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What is indicated by an intermittent diagnostic trouble code?

options.B: Fault that occurs occasionally, often due to loose connection or heat-related issue.

explanations.A: Intermittent codes indicate connection, heat soak, or vibration-related problems.
explanations.B: Permanent failure would set consistent codes.
explanations.C: All codes indicate abnormal operation.
explanations.D: Fuel type does not cause intermittent codes.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What communication protocol is commonly used for heavy equipment diagnostics?

options.B: J1939 CAN bus.

explanations.A: J1939 is standard CAN bus protocol for heavy equipment and trucks.
explanations.B: Morse code is not used for vehicle diagnostics.
explanations.C: FM radio is not a diagnostic protocol.
explanations.D: Bluetooth audio is for entertainment, not diagnostics.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What should be done if a DTC returns immediately after clearing?

options.A: Clear it repeatedly until it stays cleared.
options.B: Diagnose the circuit/component as the fault is still present.

explanations.A: Immediate return indicates active fault requiring diagnosis and repair.
explanations.B: Repeated clearing does not fix the problem.
explanations.C: ECM is rarely the cause; circuit diagnosis comes first.
explanations.D: Returning code indicates real problem requiring attention.

questions.subtask: F-15.01 Reads diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs)
questions.question: What information do diagnostic trouble codes provide?

options.A: Exact failed component and repair procedure.
options.B: General area of fault requiring further diagnosis.

explanations.A: Codes direct technician to affected system for detailed diagnosis.
explanations.B: Codes indicate problem area, not exact failed part.
explanations.C: Codes are diagnostic aids, not complete repair information.
explanations.D: Codes are essential diagnostic starting point.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What is the purpose of monitoring live data parameters with a scan tool?

options.B: To observe real-time sensor values and system operation.

explanations.A: Scan tools are diagnostic equipment, not entertainment.
explanations.B: Code clearing is separate function from parameter monitoring.
explanations.C: Live data shows actual sensor readings and system performance for diagnosis.
explanations.D: Monitoring does not change engine operation.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring coolant temperature parameters, what indicates a faulty sensor?

options.A: Temperature reading matches actual engine temperature.
options.B: Temperature reads -40C or stays at single value regardless of engine temperature.

explanations.A: Accurate reading indicates proper sensor function.
explanations.B: Normal sensor response to engine warm-up.
explanations.C: Fixed or default value indicates open circuit or failed sensor.
explanations.D: Slight decrease is normal when thermostat opens and fresh coolant circulates.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What parameter should be monitored to verify proper throttle position sensor operation?

options.B: Throttle position percentage changing smoothly with pedal movement.

explanations.A: Fuel pressure does not indicate TPS function.
explanations.B: TPS percentage should change proportionally with throttle pedal position.
explanations.C: Oil temperature is unrelated to TPS operation.
explanations.D: Battery voltage alone does not verify TPS operation.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring hydraulic pressure parameters, what indicates a problem?

options.A: Pressure within specified range during operation.
options.B: Pressure significantly below specification or erratic readings.

explanations.A: Low or erratic pressure indicates pump wear, leaks, or sensor problems.
explanations.B: Pressure within range indicates normal operation.
explanations.C: Pressure increase under load is normal system response.
explanations.D: Some pressure variation with engine speed is normal.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What does monitoring injector pulse width reveal?

options.B: Duration of fuel injector opening time.

explanations.A: Pulse width indicates how long injector is commanded open, showing fuel delivery.
explanations.B: Wheel speed is separate parameter.
explanations.C: Coolant flow is separate from injection timing.
explanations.D: Brake pads are mechanical, not monitored electronically.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring parameters during a road test, what indicates intermittent sensor failure?

options.B: Sudden spikes, dropouts, or irrational values during operation.
options.D: Values that match service manual specifications.

explanations.A: Steady readings indicate normal operation.
explanations.B: Specifications indicate proper function.
explanations.C: Gradual changes are normal response to operating conditions.
explanations.D: Sudden irrational changes indicate intermittent connection or sensor problems.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What parameter indicates proper oxygen sensor operation?

options.B: Voltage cycling between rich and lean (0.1-0.9V) in closed loop.

explanations.A: Healthy O2 sensor switches voltage rapidly in closed loop operation.
explanations.B: Fixed reading indicates failed or lazy sensor.
explanations.C: Zero voltage indicates lean condition or failed sensor.
explanations.D: Maximum voltage indicates rich condition or failed sensor.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring transmission parameters, what indicates clutch slippage?

options.B: Input speed higher than expected output speed ratio.

explanations.A: This would be normal in direct drive, not all gears.
explanations.B: Slippage causes heat increase, not decrease.
explanations.C: Speed mismatch indicates clutch not fully engaging, allowing slip.
explanations.D: Zero speed means stopped, not slipping.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What does monitoring turbocharger boost pressure parameters help diagnose?

options.B: Turbo performance, boost leaks, or wastegate problems.

explanations.A: Brake wear is mechanical inspection, not boost pressure related.
explanations.B: Boost pressure reveals turbo efficiency and boost system integrity.
explanations.C: Tire pressure is separate system.
explanations.D: Coolant level does not affect boost pressure reading.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring voltage parameters at various engine speeds, what should occur?

options.B: Voltage remains stable within 13.5-14.5V range.
options.C: Voltage drops to zero at idle.

explanations.A: Voltage should remain stable due to regulator.
explanations.B: Voltage should never drop to zero with engine running.
explanations.C: Voltage regulator maintains constant charging voltage across RPM range.
explanations.D: Voltage above 15V indicates overcharging condition.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: What does monitoring differential pressure across a diesel particulate filter (DPF) indicate?

options.B: Transmission temperature.

explanations.A: Battery state is measured differently.
explanations.B: Transmission temperature is separate parameter.
explanations.C: Differential pressure indicates soot loading and need for regeneration.
explanations.D: Tire wear is visual inspection.

questions.subtask: F-15.02 Monitors parameters
questions.question: When monitoring parameters, what indicates a mass airflow sensor problem?

options.A: MAF reading matches expected airflow for engine speed and load.
options.B: MAF reading is excessively high, low, or does not change with throttle.

explanations.A: Fixed or irrational MAF values indicate sensor contamination or failure.
explanations.B: Matching expected values indicates proper function.
explanations.C: Increase with acceleration is normal response.
explanations.D: Lower reading at idle is normal due to reduced airflow.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: A scan tool shows coolant temperature at -40C while engine is hot. What does this indicate?

options.B: Open circuit in coolant temperature sensor or wiring.

explanations.A: -40C is default value, not actual temperature.
explanations.B: Low coolant affects actual temperature, not sensor reading default.
explanations.C: Stuck thermostat would show different symptoms.
explanations.D: -40C is typical default value indicating open circuit condition.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting voltage drop test results, what indicates excessive resistance?

options.B: Greater than 0.5V drop on ground circuit during cranking.

explanations.A: Zero drop is ideal but practically uncommon.
explanations.B: Voltage drop exceeding 0.5V indicates high resistance requiring repair.
explanations.C: 0.1V drop is acceptable and indicates good connection.
explanations.D: Negative reading indicates reversed test lead connection.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: A compression test shows one cylinder significantly lower than others. What does this indicate?

options.B: Possible worn rings, valves, or head gasket leak in that cylinder.

explanations.A: Significant difference indicates problem, not normal variation.
explanations.B: Battery voltage affects cranking speed, not compression readings comparison.
explanations.C: Low compression in one cylinder indicates internal engine problem.
explanations.D: Fuel pressure does not affect compression test results.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting alternator ripple voltage test, what indicates failed diode?

options.A: No AC voltage present (less than 0.1V AC).
options.B: Excessive AC voltage (greater than 0.5V AC) in DC output.

explanations.A: Minimal AC voltage indicates good diode rectification.
explanations.B: 14.5V DC is normal charging voltage.
explanations.C: Excessive AC ripple indicates one or more diodes have failed.
explanations.D: Zero voltage indicates different problem, not ripple.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting hydraulic flow test results, what indicates pump wear?

options.B: Flow rate significantly below specifications at rated pressure and speed.

explanations.A: Matching specs indicates proper pump condition.
explanations.B: While flow is related to speed, matching alone doesn't indicate condition.
explanations.C: Flow should decrease slightly with pressure increase due to leakage.
explanations.D: Reduced flow at proper speed and pressure indicates internal pump wear.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: A fuel pressure test shows pressure drops rapidly after pump shuts off. What does this indicate?

options.B: Leaking injector, fuel pressure regulator, or check valve.

explanations.A: Pressure should hold for specified time after shutdown.
explanations.B: Pump strength does not prevent pressure drop after shutdown.
explanations.C: Rapid pressure loss indicates internal system leak preventing pressure retention.
explanations.D: Filter condition does not affect pressure retention.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting an oscilloscope pattern of sensor signal, what indicates a faulty sensor?

options.B: Erratic pattern with dropouts, spikes, or distortion.
options.C: Signal amplitude changes with sensor input.

explanations.A: Smooth pattern indicates proper sensor function.
explanations.B: Correct frequency indicates proper operation.
explanations.C: Amplitude change with input is normal sensor response.
explanations.D: Irregular waveform indicates sensor or wiring problem.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: A starter draw test shows 400 amps with slow cranking speed. What does this indicate?

options.B: High resistance in starter motor or excessive mechanical load.

explanations.A: Excessive amperage with slow cranking indicates problem.
explanations.B: 400A is excessive for typical cranking.
explanations.C: Low battery would show low amperage, not high.
explanations.D: High current with low speed indicates binding, worn starter, or engine problems.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting insulation resistance test results on a motor, what indicates acceptable insulation?

options.B: Several megohms (M) to ground.

explanations.A: Zero ohms indicates complete short to ground.
explanations.B: High resistance (megohms) indicates good insulation integrity.
explanations.C: 100 ohms is too low, indicating insulation breakdown.
explanations.D: Negative resistance is impossible, indicates meter error.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: A circuit resistance test shows infinite resistance. What does this indicate?

options.B: Open circuit or broken wire.

explanations.A: Continuity shows low resistance, not infinite.
explanations.B: Infinite resistance indicates no current path, circuit is open.
explanations.C: Short circuit shows very low or zero resistance.
explanations.D: Normal circuit shows measurable resistance based on component values.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: When interpreting battery load test results, battery voltage is 9.2V after 15 seconds under load. What does this indicate?

options.B: Battery is marginal, retest after charging.

explanations.A: Voltage below 9.6V indicates failure.
explanations.B: Voltage below 9.6V during load test indicates battery failure.
explanations.C: Battery below 9.6V must be replaced.
explanations.D: Such low voltage indicates cell failure, not marginal condition.

questions.subtask: F-15.03 Interprets test results
questions.question: What does interpreting a 5-volt reference voltage at 4.8V indicate?

options.B: Possible short to ground or high resistance in reference circuit.

explanations.A: 5V reference should be close to 5.0V, 4.8V is low.
explanations.B: Alternator output does not directly affect 5V reference.
explanations.C: Reference voltage is regulated separately from charging voltage.
explanations.D: Reduced reference voltage indicates partial short or high resistance affecting sensors.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What is the correct method to test a relay?

options.B: Apply voltage to coil and verify contacts close, check for continuity through contacts.
options.C: Shake it and listen for rattle.
options.D: Test with circuit connected under full load.

explanations.A: Visual inspection cannot verify electrical function.
explanations.B: Relay should be tested isolated from circuit for accurate results.
explanations.C: Shake test is crude and unreliable.
explanations.D: Proper bench test verifies coil operation and contact function.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing a switch, what indicates proper operation?

options.A: Infinite resistance in both on and off positions.
options.B: Zero resistance when closed, infinite resistance when open.

explanations.A: Infinite resistance in both positions indicates failed switch.
explanations.B: High resistance indicates poor contact or failure.
explanations.C: Switch should show continuity when closed, open circuit when off.
explanations.D: Mechanical feel does not confirm electrical function.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What is the proper method to test a solenoid coil?

options.B: Measure coil resistance with ohmmeter and compare to specifications.

explanations.A: Continuous voltage application can overheat and damage coil.
explanations.B: Water exposure will damage electrical components.
explanations.C: Shorting terminals can damage coil.
explanations.D: Resistance measurement verifies coil integrity without damage.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing circuit continuity, what reading indicates a good circuit?

options.B: Low resistance (near zero ohms for wire).

explanations.A: Infinite resistance indicates open circuit.
explanations.B: Negative resistance is impossible with standard meter.
explanations.C: Fluctuating resistance indicates loose connection or damaged wire.
explanations.D: Low resistance confirms complete circuit path without breaks.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What is the correct procedure to test a temperature sensor?

options.A: Measure resistance at various temperatures and compare to specifications.
options.B: Apply maximum voltage and observe.

explanations.A: Excessive voltage can damage sensor.
explanations.B: Resistance should change predictably with temperature per manufacturer specs.
explanations.C: Internal sensor function cannot be verified visually.
explanations.D: Proper testing should precede installation.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing a pressure transducer, what method is used?

options.A: Apply known pressure and measure voltage/current output.
options.B: Shake and listen for noise.
options.D: Measure with no pressure applied only.

explanations.A: Electrical function must be tested, not just visually inspected.
explanations.B: Shaking does not verify sensor accuracy.
explanations.C: Output should correspond to applied pressure per calibration specifications.
explanations.D: Transducer must be tested across its pressure range.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What tool is used to test for AC voltage in an alternator output?

options.B: Multimeter set to AC voltage mode.

explanations.A: AC voltage measurement reveals diode integrity through ripple voltage.
explanations.B: Test light cannot measure AC voltage level.
explanations.C: Compression tester is for engine cylinders.
explanations.D: Torque wrench is for fastener tightening.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing a wiring harness for shorts to ground, what indicates a short?

options.B: Low resistance (near zero ohms) to ground.

explanations.A: Low resistance to ground indicates insulation failure and short circuit.
explanations.B: Infinite resistance indicates good insulation, no short.
explanations.C: Wire gauge resistance is measured along wire length, not to ground.
explanations.D: High resistance indicates good insulation.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What is the proper method to test a diode?

options.A: Measure resistance in both directions; should show low in one, high in other.
options.B: Apply maximum voltage until it glows.

explanations.A: Excessive voltage damages diode.
explanations.B: Diode should conduct in forward bias, block in reverse bias.
explanations.C: Short circuit test will destroy diode.
explanations.D: Diodes can and should be tested with proper method.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing a motor for a short to ground, what is the acceptable reading?

options.B: Infinite or very high resistance to ground.

explanations.A: Zero ohms indicates direct short requiring replacement.
explanations.B: High resistance indicates good insulation and no short to ground.
explanations.C: 50 ohms is too low, indicates insulation breakdown.
explanations.D: Fluctuating reading indicates intermittent short or bad connection.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: What is the correct method to test a capacitor?

options.A: Discharge safely, then measure capacitance with appropriate meter.
options.B: Short terminals with screwdriver.
options.C: Apply voltage and watch for sparks.

explanations.A: Capacitor function cannot be determined visually.
explanations.B: Dangerous and can damage capacitor or cause injury.
explanations.C: Unsafe testing method.
explanations.D: Safe discharge followed by capacitance measurement verifies function.

questions.subtask: F-15.04 Tests system circuitry and components
questions.question: When testing a Hall effect sensor, what tool is most appropriate?

options.B: Oscilloscope or voltmeter to observe signal pattern.

explanations.A: Compression tester is for engine cylinders.
explanations.B: Tire gauge measures pressure, not electrical signals.
explanations.C: Torque wrench is for fasteners.
explanations.D: Oscilloscope shows on/off pattern as magnet passes sensor.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What is the first step before updating ECM software?

options.B: Verify correct software version for the specific unit and back up existing programming.

explanations.A: Wrong software can damage system; backup allows recovery if needed.
explanations.B: Battery must remain connected for programming.
explanations.C: Engine should be off during programming.
explanations.D: ECM remains installed during software update.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What can happen if battery voltage drops during a software update?

options.B: ECM can be corrupted and require replacement or recovery programming.

explanations.A: Low voltage interrupts update process.
explanations.B: Voltage drop causes problems, not improvements.
explanations.C: Voltage loss will interrupt and potentially corrupt programming.
explanations.D: Interrupted update can corrupt software, rendering ECM non-functional.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What tool is required to update vehicle management system software?

options.B: Manufacturer-specific diagnostic software and interface.

explanations.A: Wrenches are mechanical tools, not for software updates.
explanations.B: Test light cannot program electronic modules.
explanations.C: Proper software and communication interface required for reprogramming.
explanations.D: Compression gauge tests engine cylinders.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: After completing a software update, what must be done?

options.B: Verify update success, clear DTCs if necessary, perform system initialization procedures.

explanations.A: ECM needs time to complete initialization.
explanations.B: Post-update procedures are critical for proper operation.
explanations.C: Verification and initialization ensure system operates properly with new software.
explanations.D: ECM should remain installed; bench test is unnecessary.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: Why might software updates be necessary on heavy equipment?

options.A: To fix known bugs, improve performance, or update emission calibrations.
options.B: To increase fuel consumption.

explanations.A: Updates aim to improve or maintain efficiency, not worsen it.
explanations.B: Updates address issues, improve function, and maintain compliance.
explanations.C: Updates optimize performance, not reduce it arbitrarily.
explanations.D: Software updates provide functional improvements.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What precaution should be taken regarding electrical loads during software update?

options.A: Turn on all accessories to test.
options.B: Turn off all unnecessary electrical loads and use battery charger if needed.

explanations.A: Additional loads drain battery during programming.
explanations.B: Minimizing loads and maintaining voltage prevents programming failure.
explanations.C: Engine should not run during software update.
explanations.D: Alternator should remain connected if engine were running, but engine is off.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What information must be recorded before performing software update?

options.B: Current software version, calibration data, and unit serial number.

explanations.A: Documentation is critical for tracking and troubleshooting.
explanations.B: While operator info may be recorded, technical data is essential.
explanations.C: Tire pressure is unrelated to software updates.
explanations.D: Records allow verification of correct update and rollback if needed.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What might need to be reprogrammed after engine ECM software update?

options.B: Injector trim codes, sensor calibrations, or customer parameters.

explanations.A: Tire sensors are separate system.
explanations.B: Many systems require recalibration after ECM update.
explanations.C: Radio settings are separate entertainment system.
explanations.D: Calibration data may be reset and require re-entry for proper operation.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What is the purpose of reading DTCs before software update?

options.B: To document existing faults and determine if update addresses them.

explanations.A: DTCs may indicate why update is needed or reveal hardware issues.
explanations.B: DTCs have no effect on download speed.
explanations.C: DTCs do not affect warranty.
explanations.D: Documentation helps determine if update resolves issues or if hardware repair needed.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What should be done if software update fails partway through?

options.B: Attempt recovery programming or contact manufacturer technical support.

explanations.A: ECM may be recoverable with proper procedures.
explanations.B: Recovery procedures may restore functionality or manufacturer assistance needed.
explanations.C: Failed update leaves ECM inoperable.
explanations.D: Incomplete update prevents proper system operation.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: What communication protocol is commonly used for heavy equipment ECM programming?

options.B: J1939 CAN bus or manufacturer proprietary protocol.

explanations.A: Bluetooth audio is not used for ECM programming.
explanations.B: Radio is not data communication protocol.
explanations.C: J1939 and proprietary protocols enable ECM communication and programming.
explanations.D: Morse code is not used in modern vehicle programming.

questions.subtask: F-16.01 Updates component software
questions.question: Why must ignition be on during software update?

options.A: To play radio during wait time.
options.B: To power ECM and communication circuits for programming.
options.D: Ignition should be off during updates.

explanations.A: Radio operation is not reason for ignition requirement.
explanations.B: Ignition must be on to power control modules.
explanations.C: Engine should be off, but ignition provides electrical power.
explanations.D: ECM requires power to receive and process new programming.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When replacing an ECM, what must be programmed into the new unit?

options.B: Vehicle configuration, calibrations, and security parameters.

explanations.A: New ECM requires programming to match vehicle specifications.
explanations.B: Radio is separate system.
explanations.C: Complete vehicle configuration must be loaded for proper operation.
explanations.D: Many more parameters than tire size require programming.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: What should be verified before replacing a sensor?

options.A: Sensor is actually faulty, not wiring or connector issues.
options.B: Coolant level.

explanations.A: Wiring problems often misdiagnosed as sensor failure; verify actual cause.
explanations.B: Coolant level is unrelated to sensor testing.
explanations.C: Tire pressure is separate from electronic sensor diagnosis.
explanations.D: Radio function is irrelevant to sensor replacement.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When replacing an electronic control module, what safety precaution is critical?

options.B: Disconnect battery and follow ESD protection procedures.
options.C: Use maximum torque on mounting bolts.

explanations.A: Engine must be off and power disconnected.
explanations.B: Prevents electrical damage and protects sensitive electronics from static discharge.
explanations.C: Over-torquing can crack ECM housing.
explanations.D: ECM should never be submerged in liquid.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: After replacing a throttle position sensor, what procedure is typically required?

options.B: Calibration or relearn procedure using scan tool.

explanations.A: Calibration ensures ECM recognizes sensor positions accurately.
explanations.B: ECM replacement is not necessary for sensor replacement.
explanations.C: Sensor position must be learned by ECM for proper throttle response.
explanations.D: Oil change is unrelated to TPS replacement.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: What is the proper handling procedure for electronic control modules?

options.B: Use ESD protection, avoid extreme temperatures, prevent moisture exposure.

explanations.A: ECMs contain sensitive electronics requiring careful handling.
explanations.B: Dropping will damage electronic components.
explanations.C: Sunlight creates heat and UV exposure that can damage ECM.
explanations.D: Proper handling prevents static damage, thermal shock, and corrosion.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When replacing wiring harness connectors, what ensures reliable connection?

options.B: Clean terminals, ensure proper pin alignment, verify locking mechanisms engage.
options.C: Apply excessive dielectric grease inside terminals.
options.D: Use any available connector regardless of type.

explanations.A: Forcing can bend pins and damage connectors.
explanations.B: Proper preparation and installation ensure good electrical connection.
explanations.C: Excess grease inside terminals can insulate contact surfaces.
explanations.D: Connector type must match electrical and environmental requirements.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: What must be done after replacing an injector on an electronically controlled engine?

options.B: Program injector calibration codes into ECM.

explanations.A: Calibration codes must be entered for proper fuel delivery.
explanations.B: ECM does not need replacement for injector change.
explanations.C: Each injector has unique flow characteristics requiring ECM programming.
explanations.D: While contamination should be addressed, immediate oil change isn't always required.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When replacing an ABS wheel speed sensor, what should be verified?

options.B: Sensor air gap or tone ring condition, secure mounting, and proper wiring.

explanations.A: Proper gap and clean tone ring ensure accurate speed signal generation.
explanations.B: Oil level is unrelated to ABS sensor installation.
explanations.C: Tire pressure alone does not verify sensor installation.
explanations.D: Radio is separate system from ABS.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: What is required when replacing a turbocharger actuator on electronically controlled systems?

options.B: Actuator calibration or relearn procedure to set reference positions.

explanations.A: Electronic actuators require calibration for proper boost control.
explanations.B: ECM must learn actuator range for accurate turbo control.
explanations.C: Engine removal is not needed for actuator calibration.
explanations.D: Only actuator calibration is required.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When repairing wiring harness, what type of connectors should be used?

options.B: Proper sealed automotive connectors rated for application.

explanations.A: Automotive-grade sealed connectors withstand vibration, moisture, and temperature.
explanations.B: Wire nuts are not suitable for vehicle vibration and environmental exposure.
explanations.C: Tape alone provides inadequate connection and protection.
explanations.D: Connector must meet environmental and current requirements.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: What should be checked after replacing any electronic sensor?

options.B: Verify sensor reading is within normal range and DTCs are clear.

explanations.A: Confirms sensor operates properly and system recognizes it correctly.
explanations.B: Tire tread is unrelated to sensor installation verification.
explanations.C: Coolant condition is separate from electronic sensor verification.
explanations.D: Wiper blades are unrelated to electronic sensor replacement.

questions.subtask: F-16.02 Repairs components
questions.question: When replacing a hydraulic system pressure sensor, what must be ensured?

options.A: Sensor thread type, pressure rating, and electrical connection match specifications.
options.B: Sensor is any color.

explanations.A: Proper specifications prevent leaks, damage, and ensure accurate readings.
explanations.B: Color is cosmetic; specifications are critical.
explanations.C: Incorrect sensor can fail catastrophically or give wrong readings.
explanations.D: Proper thread sealant prevents leaks in hydraulic systems.
